docs.title: Toolbox
docs.text: A privacy-first tool to install MCP servers and background agents for your personal data.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Toolbox is a CLI tool for installing and managing MCP servers and background agents, made for developers.

  • Install MCP servers with background agents using tb install <appname>
  • Support for popular developer tools (GitHub, Slack, Discord, Obsidian, Gmail, etc.)
  • Compatible with multiple clients (Claude Desktop, Cursor)
  • Choose between fully local or free hosted options

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Install via uv
uv tool install --prerelease allow --python 3.12 -U syft-toolbox

# Verify installation
tb info

docs.title: Basic Commands
docs.text:
# List available apps
tb list-store

# Install an app
tb install slack-mcp

# List installed apps
tb list

# Show app details
tb show <appname>

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text: Toolbox provides a simple way to send notifications from your trigger scripts and MCP servers using ntfy.sh.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
Your default notification topic is automatically configured during tb setup. To view or change it:

# View current default notification topic
tb settings

# Set a new default topic
tb set-notification-topic <topic>

To receive notifications on your phone:

  1. Install the ntfy.sh app
  2. Subscribe to your topic (e.g., tb-username-a3f2)

docs.title: From Trigger Scripts
docs.text:
Use the notify function from toolbox_events to send notifications:

from toolbox_events import notify

# Simple notification (uses default topic)
notify("Task completed successfully")

# With title and priority
notify(
    message="10 new repositories found matching 'MCP'",
    title="GitHub Search Results",
    priority=4  # 1=min, 2=low, 3=default, 4=high, 5=urgent
)

# With custom topic and tags
notify(
    message="Server backup completed",
    title="Backup Status",
    tags=["backup", "success"],
    topic="server-alerts"
)

docs.title: Priority Levels
docs.text:
Notifications support 5 priority levels:

  • 1 - Minimum priority
  • 2 - Low priority
  • 3 - Default priority (default)
  • 4 - High priority
  • 5 - Urgent priority

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
The notification system can be configured via environment variables:

# Use custom ntfy server (default: https://ntfy.sh)
export TOOLBOX_NOTIFIER_SERVER_URL=https://your-ntfy-server.com

# Set default topic
export TOOLBOX_NOTIFIER_DEFAULT_TOPIC=my-notifications

docs.title: Example: Notification in Event-Driven Trigger
docs.text:
from toolbox_events import get_events, notify

# Process events and notify on important ones
events = get_events()

important_count = 0
for event in events:
    if event.name == "critical.error":
        important_count += 1

if important_count > 0:
    notify(
        f"⚠️ {important_count} errors detected",
        title="System Alert",
        priority=4,
        tags=["error", "alert"]
    )

docs.title: Triggers
docs.text: Toolbox can run scripts defined by you on a schedule. This is useful for automating tasks as part of your MCP pipeline.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
First, to be able to run triggers, you need to install the toolbox daemon. This will add the toolbox daemon to your launchd, so it will start automatically when you login.

tb daemon install

To uninstall and remove from launchd:

tb daemon uninstall

To see the status of the daemon:

tb daemon status

docs.title: Creating Triggers
docs.text:
As example, we have provided a script to search github for repositories with the keyword "MCP".

# Run `search_github_trigger.py` daily at 12:00
tb trigger add --name "github-trending" --script "examples/search_github_trigger.py" --cron "0 12 * * *"

docs.title: Managing Triggers
docs.text:
To uninstall a trigger:

tb trigger uninstall "github-trending"

To show all triggers:

tb trigger list

To show the status and last 5 executions of a trigger:

tb trigger show github-trending -n 5

docs.title: Cron Expressions
docs.text:
The --cron parameter accepts standard cron expressions to schedule triggers at a specific time or interval. For example:

  • 0 12 * * * - Daily at 12:00
  • 0 */6 * * * - Every 6 hours
  • 0 9 * * 1 - Every Monday at 9:00

For more detailed cron syntax and examples, see crontab.guru - an interactive cron expression editor and reference.

docs.title: Event-Driven Triggers
docs.text: Triggers can respond to events sent by MCP servers. Toolbox automatically configures the environment so events are routed correctly.

docs.title: Sending Events from MCP Servers
docs.text:
Toolbox receives events from all MCP servers launched by Toolbox. Use the toolbox_events package to send events to the daemon:

from toolbox_events import send_event

# Send an event when something happens
send_event(
    name="file_processed",
    data={"filename": "document.pdf", "pages": 10}
)

Each event automatically includes:

  • source - The name of the MCP server that sent the event
  • timestamp - The time the event was sent

docs.title: Receiving Events in Trigger Scripts
docs.text:
Toolbox automatically sends events to trigger scripts that are registered to listen for them. Scripts receive all matching events:

from toolbox_events import get_events

# Get all events for this trigger
events = get_events()

for event in events:
    print(f"{event.name}: {event.data}")

docs.title: Creating Event-Based Triggers
docs.text:
Use the trigger add command to create triggers that respond to specific events.

Example: Create a trigger that responds to file events from the obsidian-mcp server:

tb trigger add \
    --name "obsidian-event-processor" \
    --script "/path/to/your/script.py" \
    --event "file.created" \
    --event "file.modified" \
    --event "file.deleted" \
    --event-source "obsidian-mcp"

docs.title: Event Filtering
docs.text:
• Multiple events/sources: Provide --event and --event-source multiple times to listen for multiple events from multiple sources
  • All sources: Omit --event-source to listen for events from all sources
  • All events from a source: Omit --event to listen for all events from specific sources
  • Schedule-only: Omit both --event and --event-source to run only on schedule without listening for events

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Before installing Toolbox, ensure you have:

  • Python 3.12 or later
  • uv - Fast Python package installer

docs.title: Install from PyPI
docs.text:
The recommended way to install Toolbox:

uv tool install --prerelease allow --python 3.12 -U syft-toolbox

Verify the installation:

tb info

docs.title: Install from Source
docs.text:
For development or latest features:

git clone https://github.com/OpenMined/toolbox.git
cd toolbox
uv pip install -e .

docs.title: CLang Issues
docs.text:
If you encounter CLang errors during installation:

uv python install --reinstall

This fixes Python in uv.

docs.title: C++ Include Errors
docs.text:
If you see #include <string> errors:

CXXFLAGS="-isystem $(xcrun --show-sdk-path)/usr/include/c++/v1" uv pip install -e .

docs.title: Permission Issues
docs.text: If you get permission errors, ensure you have write access to the uv tool directory. You may need to use sudo or adjust your PATH.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: After installation, proceed to the Quick Start guide to install your first MCP server.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will get you up and running with Toolbox in minutes.

docs.title: 1. Verify Installation
docs.text:
After installing Toolbox, verify it's working:

tb info

docs.title: 2. Initial Setup
docs.text:
Run the setup command to configure Toolbox:

tb setup

This will:

  • Configure your notification settings
  • Set up analytics preferences
  • Create necessary directories

docs.title: Browse Available MCP Servers
docs.text:
See what's available to install:

tb list-store

docs.title: Install Your First MCP Server
docs.text:
Let's start with a popular one - Slack:

tb install slack-mcp

Follow the prompts to:

  1. Authenticate with Slack
  2. Configure which workspaces to monitor
  3. Set up any background agents

docs.title: List Installed Apps
docs.text:
View all your installed MCP servers:

tb list

docs.title: Check App Details
docs.text:
Get detailed information about an installed app:

tb show slack-mcp

docs.title: View Logs
docs.text:
Monitor what your MCP server is doing:

# View recent logs
tb log slack-mcp

# Follow logs in real-time
tb log slack-mcp -f

docs.title: Using with Claude
docs.text:
Once you've installed an MCP server, it's automatically available in Claude Desktop:

  1. Open Claude Desktop
  2. Start a new conversation
  3. Your MCP servers will be available as tools Claude can use
  4. Try asking: "Show me my recent Slack messages"
